Posts.Content: Very encouraging post! 'preciate dat. Pretty high PSAs with 3+3 gives me hope! thanks, jerry
Posts.Title: 5 days post surgery

Posts.Content: Greater Atlanta area. Travel would be very difficult. Would like to be able to travel but have local issues I can not get out of. Not to mention insurance issues.
Posts.Title: Finding an experienced surgeon. How to?

Posts.Content: OK, so every where I look I'm seeing that using the Da Vinci has a steep learning curve. Advice is a Dr needs to have done 250-300 before having it down. So my ??, is how do I find a Dr that has this expertise? Of course the obvious is to ask. Ok, so I ask my 36 year old Uro. and he says he's done 32. Not good. What does one do from there. Make an appointment with another Dr just to ask him/her? Then another, then another? Is there a place to find these things out? thanks guys, jerry

Posts.Title: Finding an experienced surgeon. How to?

Posts.Content: Devouring Dr Walsh's book. There is so much info available on the net it is just more than I can usefully take in. It's like the black hole of knowledge, so much knowledge, is such a small place, that even light can't escape it's gravitation pull! So I'm going to use his book as my primary source. (keeping in mind his obvious favor towards surgery) So to the point, looking at the Partin & Han tables, trying to get some idea where I might stand here's what I'm seeing. (They are pretty clear except the numbers in ()s, any help on that would be nice.) It is a combo of 3 pieces of info that make up the estimate of where one stands. The DRE, PSA, Gleason. OK, to my case. I am aware that only a biopsy can give any indication of Gleason. The DR did a DRE. I was clear w/ him that I wanted to know right then what he was feeling. I am aware that DRs do not want to scare there clients without cause but I wanted to know. Not knowing is the more of 2 evils for me. He said that he may have found a little firmness but was dismissive, implying he was not so concerned. Question: Dr W says either the DRE was non-palpable w psa high , palpable on less than 1/2 on 1 lobe, palpable on more than 1/2 of one lobe or on both lobes. ?? Ya reckon the dr might have been less than forth coming. Just a guess I know, but I am wondering just how clear a DRE is. "maybe a little firmness"??? But this is a side issue. The real issue is this, as I mentioned in my first post I am an avid MNT biker. Tend to be a little on the extreme side. (it's a personality thing) What I did not mention is that I was having additional seat issues. Had a rash that was flaring up. (1-3hrs riding a day does things!) To compensate I was sitting on my seat kinda funny which in hind sight was not so wise. I am convinced I was putting substantial additional, bouncing, pressure on my perineum. I explained this to both my primary and uro drs. (Bear with me guys, gettin' to da point) My primary did a PCA--18.7 SCAR--EEE! My uro did another, 8 days later, with little riding and no sex. 11.4. Disappointing, as we both hoped it would be lower. He also did a fPSA, 9.5% (not good) OK, so here is the ???? There was a 40% drop in 8 days, pretty big I think. Not trying to get out of a biopsy, not considering the fPSA but I am thinking that I do not have a reliable PSA and really need some kind of base line in order to make treatment decisions. Once a biopsy is done PSAs take awhile to stabilize also so I am considering delaying the biopsy. I dread the thought of delaying as not knowing is the worst! I know this is a question I have to bring to my Dr but was wondering if any of you have any comments. Is my logic off?(personal experience goes a long way) thanks, jerry
Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Ok, apparently I am being misunderstood. I am going to get a biopsy, positively, for sure, absolutely. With the info I already have it would be more than foolish not to. The question is that I am not convinced that my PSA #s are accurate considering the 40% difference in the tests that I had 8 days apart. Here is my concern--"Scientists at John Hopkins have found more accurate way to estimate the exact extent of prostate cancer using a special table that puts these pieces together- correlating clinical stage, (which I take to mean the DRE, jm) Gleason score and PSA level-based on information from thousands of men. The Partin tables are designed to help men and their doctors predict the definitive pathological stage before treatment, and then-based on this more accurate information-determine the best course of action." Pg 194 in the 3rd addition of Walsh's book. thanks for the dialog guys, just having a place to talk things out is more than helpful, as you all know, jerry
Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Yeah I'm not totally clear on that either. If you have the book you might take a look. Maybe you might shed a little light. At the top of table 6.2 (pg195, 3rd addition, paperback) it says "PREDICTING PATHOLOGIC STAGE OF PROSTATE CANCER BASED ON CLINICAL STAGE (TNM), PSA LEVEL, AND GLEASON SCORE" (caps are his not mine) Don't know what "TNM" means. jerry
Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Not a question of if, only a question of when. jm, whew

Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Don't mean to be redundant. OK So my primary did a PSA because of urinary probs. Suspected the cause was my some what extreme biking habits. PSA 18.7 Uro in 8 days, backed off the bike. PSA11+ a 7 point drop. When he suggested a biopsy I asked about the drop in PSA and if it might not continue. His response was that I could wait another 6 weeks but if the high PSA was from inflammation my fPSA (9%+) should not be so low. SO, question is, anyone know if anything OTHER than cancer would cause a low fPSA read? Also, I know PSA# flux some but 7points!? By the way, wasn't clear--biopsy the 19th of this month. Also, have a good bike seat!
Posts.Title: Newbie: This is not looking good.

Posts.Title: Newbie: This is not looking good.

Posts.Content: Hey guys, I can think of a million things I would like to be doing right now, joining this forum is not even one of them. My quick story: I'm an avid mountain biker, ride daily and am in the best shape I've ever been in as an adult. Last summer I had a little bout with what turns out to be my prostate. Had some trouble tinkling, a bit of discomfort and stream issues. Figured it had to do with the fact I spent between 1 and 3 hrs a day on a seat the size of a banana. (reasonable) Thought about going to the Dr but it quickly resolved itself. The trouble returned a couple of weeks ago but much worse. Made an appointment. By the time I went it was already resolving itself once again. Dr ordered a PSA. Couple of days later he contacted me. PSA 18.7 Made app. with urologist. Did DRE and new PSA. He did not seem too concerned. Said he felt what might be a little firmness but expected the prob was the biking. PSA came back 11.4, fPSA 9.5% Biopsy the 19th. Been googling and got a copy of Dr Walsh's book. (Already owe y'all one for that) Well, as you know more about this subject than I, you know what I mean by "not looking good" PSA north of 10, fPSA south of 10. You all are aware of how I'm feeling right now. Total game changer. Not really looking for sympathy, just wanting to introduce myself. jerry
Posts.Title: Newbie: This is not looking good.
